dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We pan across the city skyline, a beautiful sight -- over which we hear the CLACKING of computer keys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wall of glass offers a letter-boxed view of a sleek conference room. Amber sconces illuminate an enormous tab empty save for & YOUNG MAN at the far end - a lonely hunched over a laptop. Steadily tighten on JONATHAN MESSER (late 20s), trim buil not entirely at ease in a suit. Likeable features suggest gentle, intelligent demeanor. Grids of numbers from the laptop screen reflect off his glasses. Tired, he rubs his eyes, continues typing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Briefcase in hand, Jonathan walks a vacant corridor of em cubicles. In a few offices lights are still on; the figur of YOUNG MEN AND WOMEN at work are blurred like photos ou focus behind the frosted-glass of closed doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waiting for his train, Jonathan pauses at a news kiosk.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Do-you have tomorrow's Times yet? The grizzled OLD MAN behind the counter doesn't look up.

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: It is tomorrow. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Right. I forgot. The Old man grudgingly bends to cut the plastic on a fres stack of newspapers. As he does, Jonathan glances at nume porn magazines on display. Naked women smile back at him

dialogues.speaker: OLD MAN
dialogues.text: Anything else?

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Uh - no. No that's it, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonathan descends an above-ground subway stop. Neighborho streets are vacant, the clopping of his shoes the only so Jonathan turns a corner, heads for a humble duplex, the f floor marked by unlit neon: "FLEURS DE SOLANGE." He ascen the steps, his keys out --

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Jonathan! The voice from nowhere startles him - he spins to find

dialogues.speaker: SOLANGE
dialogues.text: standing in the doorway below, bundled in a ski jacket.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Solange, you're up so late?

dialogues.speaker: SOLANGE
dialogues.text: So early, Jonathan. We open in one hour. (GRINS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So tell me, you have been out with a lady friend, oui?

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: (SMILES)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Je suis desole, madame, mais no.

dialogues.speaker: SOLANGE
dialogues.text: But why else does a young man come home at such an hour?

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Just working late, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: SOLANGE
dialogues.text: Every night working late, working late. (teasing him) Ah, you can't fool me. You are Mister Mischief maker - I know this! You come by (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SOLANGE
dialogues.text: later and pick out something for your lady friend, oui?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very modest. Furnishings are nice, but sparse. Jonathan h his suit jacket in a closet of empty hangers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not much decoration other than a dated Jimmy Connors post and an old tennis trophy. Jonathan lies in bed, flipping channels on a small TV. Typical late night stuff: infommercials; CNN; a Brazilian soccer match; "Channel J" (public access) on which X-rated clips advertise phone se Jonathan lingers a moment on these explicit ads back to, the roaring soccer crowd. He closes his eyes and drifts off to the frenetic Portuguese of an unseen announ

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TWO CORPORATE LAWYERS are talking shop while pouring coff

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Excuse me. Fixing his coffee, Jonathan reaches past them. They barel give him a glance as they continue their conversation.

dialogues.speaker: LAWYER 1
dialogues.text: So, the Knicks win last night?

dialogues.speaker: LAWYER 2
dialogues.text: I'm pretty sure, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Actually, they lost by 4. Both pause, turn to Jonathan. Jonathan smiles awkwardly.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: It was supposed to be a good game though.

dialogues.speaker: LAWYER 1
dialogues.text: Oh. (back to Lawyer 2) Hey, so. did you get a chance to look over that memo from Watkins?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bustling - yet here too Jonathan is ignored as he carries coffee past ASSISTANTS and LAWYERS talking shop. He smile (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: politely at those he passes; few bother to smile in retur INT. CONFERENCE ROOM - MORNING . Again Jonathan works alone at one end of the long table, rapidly typing, eyes ping-ponging from files to laptop, beside him a meticulous arrangement of pastel-colored pos its on which are scribbled various calculations. He strik us as extremely good at his job, tackling the overwhelmin array of numbers and data with methodical assurance. Taking a break, he pauses to peer out the glass wall befo him. Behind the glass, employees pass like fish in a tank

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a stall, Jonathan is staring sleepily at patterns in t stall's marble door -- when a sudden KNOCK-KNOCK on the divider to his right startles him. He peers down and over expensive black wingtip shoes, a Wall St. Journal spread the floor. Another KNOCK-KNOCK. Confused, Jonathan turns address the divider:

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: MALE VOICE
dialogues.text: Take a look at this. The voice sounds youthful, energetic. Its owner slides hi Journal along the floor halfway between the marble divisi

dialogues.speaker: MALE VOICE
dialogues.text: The Japanese are developing a toilet that can analyze your urine for glucose levels, kidney disease, even cancer. They're referring to it as the "super bowl."

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: That certainly is

dialogues.speaker: MALE VOICE, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Of course if you've ever been to Japan, you know they're nuts about their toilets. I'm talking web sites, symposiums... Jonathan chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: MALE VOICE
dialogues.text: You think I'm kidding. They have bowls over there that cost more than a piano. What I want to know is how you're supposed to retrieve this analysis - you know, from your super bowl. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Maybe they're developing a fly with a nursing degree. A superfly.

dialogues.speaker: MALE VOICE
dialogues.text: (LAUGHS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's in there anyway?

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Uh, Jonathan Messer.

dialogues.speaker: MALE VOICE
dialogues.text: Messer... What department?

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: None. I'm from Worth and Berman. I've been over here a few wee-- A FLUSH from the next stall cuts him off. The sound of zipping up, of a belt buckled, then of a stall door openi

dialogues.speaker: MALE VOICE
dialogues.text: So you're an accountant? Jonathan follows the FOOTSTEPS, now addresses his stall d

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Audit manager, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: MALE VOICE, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: So how's it work, Rutherford Stern hires Worth and Berman to give their blessing to our books, and they send you?

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Have laptop, will travel. What about you?

dialogues.speaker: MALE VOICE, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: What about me?

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Well, I didn't get your name for one.th-- The SOUND OF A FAUCET RUNNING drowns him out.

dialogues.speaker: MALE VOICE
dialogues.text: .ose.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Sorry - I didn't catch that? (gets no response) Hello...? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MALE VOICE
dialogues.text: I said it's Wyatt. Wyatt Bose. Jonathan FLUSHES, buckles his belt, opens his stall door - only the men's room is now empty.

dialogues.speaker: COMPUVOICE
dialogues.text: Message-four. Three-oh-eight-pee-em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alone again, Jonathan listens to voice-mail on his cell phone. We..find two more batteries sitting ready in a cha

dialogues.speaker: PETERSON
dialogues.text: Jonathan? Chet Peterson. Just wanted to- confirm you're wrapping up over there at Rutherford Stern because the controller at Clancey has been on me to get someone in there by Thursday. I told him how brilliant you are, said you're the best auditor we've got. Anyway, I forwarded you some documentation... Jonathan clicks his mouse - to find 27 worth&berman.com. He reaches for his palm pilot, clic day planner, stylus writes "Clancey" into next week. Othe than places he'll be working, days-are-all entirely blank

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonathan still working. Only a few of the post-its now re on the tabletop. Yawning, he glances at his watch -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 12:53 Startled, Jonathan turns to a well-dressed young man in t doorway - penetrating eyes, playful smile, familiar voice

dialogues.speaker: WYATT
dialogues.text: Sorry if I scared you. I was heading home and saw the lights. We met before, in the can...

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Sure. It's Wyatt, right? WYATT BOSE nods as he steps into the room. There's someth very likeably "on" about him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WYATT
dialogues.text: So do you normally work this late?

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Pretty much. I'm supposed to be out of here by tomorrow so I'm just trying to finish up. What about you?

dialogues.speaker: WYATT
dialogues.text: You kidding? This is an early night. Hard to believe that once upona time a man's success was measured by how little he had to work. You know in Sweden the average worker gets 7 weeks a year vacation? (regards his stacked files) Do-you like accounting?

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: It's all right, if you enjoy working with numbers. Do you like being a lawyer?

dialogues.speaker: WYATT
dialogues.text: It's all right. If you enjoy working with assholes. Jonathan laughs, glances at his monitor screen.

dialogues.speaker: WYATT
dialogues.text: Well, I'm probably disturbing you -

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: No - it's okay. Really.

dialogues.speaker: WYATT
dialogues.text: So Worth and Berman, huh? Don't you have to like be in Mensa to work there? Jonathan smiles, shrugs modestly.

dialogues.speaker: WYATT
dialogues.text: Been with them long?

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Since my senior year of college. They subsidized my graduate degree.

dialogues.speaker: WYATT
dialogues.text: Really. So you were poor? Jonathan is given pause by the bluntness of the question. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Well - I guess you could say that. I was raised by a single mother, and she died when I was nineteen, so... yeah. It wasn't so bad though. I'm sure a lot of people have had it worse.

dialogues.speaker: WYATT
dialogues.text: Not around here. Practically every suit I know is Harvard by way of Andover.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Are you?

dialogues.speaker: WYATT
dialogues.text: Me? Hell no... I'm Princeton. By way of Exeter. Jonathan laughs. Wyatt smiles, takes a few idle paces.

dialogues.speaker: WYATT
dialogues.text: So. Jonathan. (GRINS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you say to a break?

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON A SCREENSAVER OF SWIMMING FISH. Tilt up from Jonathan's laptop screen to Wyatt and Jonathan, sitting o top of the expensive conference-table, passinga joint, staring out at the rain hammering the far windows.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: (STONED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .It's just sometimes I feel so - I don't know - removed. I mean, I work for one of the biggest accounting firms in the world, and.there's not so much as a desk there to prove it? They've decided all we need are cell phones and laptops. Messages are voice-mailed, documents e-mailed, salary's deposited online. Chet Peterson, my senior manager? I swear he wouldn't recognize me if I was sitting in his chair. Jonathan pauses, takes another drag, train of thought dri

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: I don't know... I used to have friends. But it's like I've spent so much time trying to prove myself, working these hours you look up and realize you've lost (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: everyone. Just - fell out of touch. With everyone... And I try to meet people at work. I do. But it's always the same. To the accounting staff I'm a pain because for two weeks they have to hold their breath and hope I don't pick up on any of their screw ups. And to everyone else, I'm just a temporary fixture, so why bother? The truth is, this is the first meaningful conversation I've had in I don't know how long. It's like if I disappeared tomorrow, I'm not .sure anyone other than Solange would even notice - she's my neighbor. I live on what must be the only block in Brooklyn that still isn't hip. (EXHALES)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess I just never counted-on the isolation. It's like sometimes I look through that glass, and I see life literally passing me by. Jonathan stares out the glass wall in stoned silence.

dialogues.speaker: WYATT
dialogues.text: Jonathan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: just talked for Wyatt looks at Jonathan -- and cracks up. Jonathan hesita then he too starts to laugh so now they can't stop, their laughter filling the expansive room -- until it's drowned the SOUND ADVANCE OF POURING RAIN...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonathan hurries in the cold. rain for the Times Square subway. He's just about to descend - when across he spots a beautiful YOUNG WOMAN in a camel hair coat, clutching a slim briefcase, waiting to cross the street. Jonathan gazes at her, almost gasping. She's surrounded b pedestrians with umbrellas., she's the only one without o and she's DRENCHED. But she seems content to entertain herself drawing a pattern in the drops collecting on the umbrella in front of her. Jonathan watches, intrigued - and then the rumble of the subway below reminds him he'd better move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonathan stands in a long line to buy a Metrocard, his glasses steamed up. He takes them off to wipe the lenses. JONATHAN'S POV: the entire station is a blur, all unfocus muted colors, no object discernible from another - - until his glasses return his POV to immediate focus, an sees the same Young Woman in'the camel.hair coat, a pair dollar bills in her hand, entering the station. Jonathan can't help but stare again. Despite her business attire, there's an almost childlike lightness. to her ste Jonathan notices her slim briefcase. Beneath her hand, he make out the first letter of a monogram: "S." She checks out the long line for Metrocards, considers waiting, then decides life's too short. She continues pas headed for the turnstiles. Jonathan continues to observe as she raises her briefcase then proceeds to wriggle her slender frame through the na gap in the turnstile. A PANHANDLER on the other side watches her with amusement Glancing up, she catches his eye, and blushes a mischievo smile. Once she's through, she drops her money into his collection - and slips out of view. ANGLE ON JONATHAN, still stuck on line, staring at the sp she vacated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonathan arrives as an N train pulls away, the platform n practically. empty. Weary and still a bit stoned, Jonathan peers sleepily int the dark expanse of tunnel, yawns - And then he sees "S" is waiting on the same platform. Ten yards away. He gazes at her. She's unwrapping some GUM. H watches as she puts a piece in her mouth. The sound of an ARRIVING N TRAIN. "S" heads for it, Jonat follows... The train halts. The door before him is the last of its c the door before her the first of the next. The doors open. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: II S ГўВЂВў II (turns to Jonathan) Excuse me, is this the train for canal Street? It takes Jonathan a second just to find his voice. She's more arresting up close.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Uh,.either one is R both stop there so, you know, either way, I mean, this is the right train. Yes. SOS Of Thanks. "S" enters her car. Jonathan wavers, wants to follow into car but doesn't have the nerve. He enters a different car

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonathan's slumped against a window, annoyed. at himself not getting in her car. He can see 'S'. She sits in the other car chewing her gum studies her, he's absolutely knocked out by her.

dialogues.speaker: CONDUCTOR, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Next stop Canal Street. Canal is next. He sees "S" rising to join the small crowd gathering by a door. Jonathan stands up - his last chance. Determined, he brac himself and rises, grasping his briefcase. The screeching of brakes as the train grinds into "CANAL

dialogues.speaker: STATION."
dialogues.text: A sudden JOLT of the braking train.causes Jonathan to stu slightly and his briefcase BANGS against a seat and SNAPS OPEN - contents tumbling out. His cell phone hits the flo Jonathan quickly bends for his phone - when the train lur to a halt, nearly knocking him over, and sliding his cell phone a few feet along the grimy floor. O.S. we hear the hiss of the doors opening as Jonathan gr for his phone a second before it's stepped on. He hurried stuffs it in his pocket, shoves his files and papers and paraphernalia back into his briefcase and rises to his fe - to find the doors closing, and "S" gone. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Devastated, he hurries to a window, searching the platfor the train begins to depart... He can just glimpse the bac her camel hair coat as his car is sucked back into a tunn He stands helpless, just shuts his eyes and lowers his he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonathan is pouring coffee when he brightens on hearing W enter, talking animatedly with Lawyers telling his joke, Wyatt doesn't seem to notice Jonathan. Only when the lawyers burst out laughing does Wyatt glanc up. His eyes meet Jonathan's. Jonathan smiles in greeting but Wyatt just nods coolly, returns to his fellow lawyers Jonathan's smile falters. He exits wordlessly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonathan hands over files and CD-Roms to a less than soci ASSISTANT CONTROLLER.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: I guess that's it. then. Nice meeting you.

dialogues.speaker: ASSISTANT CONTROLLER
dialogues.text: Uh huh. Jonathan turns to go, takes two paces - then turns back.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Listen - could you point me toward Wyatt Bose's office? The Assistant Controller looks up in mild annoyance.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Wyatt Bose. He's an attorney here. She sighs, put upon, then slides out a desk drawer in whi laminated page of names and extensions is taped. Jonathan eyes follow her lazy finger down the list --

dialogues.speaker: A GRUFF VOICE, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Hey, quit looking down her shirt! Jonathan instinctively leaps back from her desk, turns to find Wyatt grinning at him from down the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: WYATT
dialogues.text: Leaving, huh? So where to next? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Clancey Funds on Thursday. Clute Nichols after that. Wyatt's about to reply - when ANOTHER LAWYER passes him i the hall. Wyatt taps the lawyer's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: WYATT
dialogues.text: Hey, wait up a sec. (smiles back) Well, good meeting you, Jonathan. ,Wyatt turns and starts to walk off with the other lawyer Jonathan bends for his briefcase -

dialogues.speaker: WYATT
dialogues.text: Wait, so you have off tomorrow? Jonathan looks up to Wyatt smiling at him from down the h

dialogues.speaker: WYATT
dialogues.text: You don't happen to have .a. decent backhand, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beneath an enormous bubble dome, Jonathan and Wyatt play mixed doubles with two attractive YOUNG WOMEN (early 20's Between points, we observe from Jonathan's side of the ne Wyatt chatting up his partner. The rapport between Jonath and his partner is markedly less comfortable; he wipes hi brow, smiles at her, she forces a polite smile in return.

dialogues.speaker: SAME SCENE
dialogues.text: A good rally underway. Jonathan fires a backhand. Wyatt returns it with an audible grunt. Jonathan snaps the ball back to Wyatt's partner - only Wyatt intercepts, nailing back. Jonathan returns it with equal force. A grin on Wyatt's face as he savors the battle, blasting each ball. The women step aside. Jonathan lunges, barely managing to lob a return. Sensing victory, Wyatt raises h racket and with a guttural bark mercilessly smashes the b Jonathan dives, racket over-extended - and returns a near perfect shot just over Wyatt's head... but it lands inches outside the opposite baseline.

dialogues.speaker: WYATT
dialogues.text: Out! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Jonathan curls forward, gasping for air. Silence - then Wyatt's SOLITARY APPLAUSE echoes in the humid space.

dialogues.speaker: WYATT
dialogues.text: Commiserations, Messer. Good game. They shake hands at the net. Jonathan is exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: WYATT
dialogues.text: (WARMLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Develop akiller instinct and you'll beat the crap out of me. Jonathan turns to commiserate with his partner - but she' already gone to join her friend. Jonathan crashes out on court. From his low angle he watches as Wyatt goes over t the girls and says something that causes a burst of laugh The girls finally wave goodbye. Wyatt hops over the net.

dialogues.speaker: WYATT
dialogues.text: They asked if we'd fancy a post-game cocktail. Don't worry, I got us out of it. Jonathan is barely able to speak.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Oh? I would've been happy to.

dialogues.speaker: WYATT
dialogues.text: Are you kidding? They're a couple of first years at Merrill. Screw that, we can do better. Hey, you OK? Jonathan nods as an amused Wyatt helps him to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soft jazz plays as Wyatt leads Jonathan past the bar area Wyatt is admiring Jonathan's weathered tennis racket.

dialogues.speaker: WYATT
dialogues.text: Man, I remember when these first came out. I think I was a frosh at boarding school. (chuckles; fingers a string) Jeez, are these strings natural gut?

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Actually, it's a hybrid weave: natural gut and Kevlar. They're pretty obscure now. I should replace them, they're all frayed... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Looking up, Jonathan abruptly slows his pace, his eyes suddenly fixed on a woman sitting at the far end of the b From behind, it looks remarkably like "S"... Only, as she turns, her profile proves otherwise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wyatt and Jonathan in towels, heading for the showers. Jonathan still deep in the 'S' moment -

dialogues.speaker: WYATT
dialogues.text: Have you ever considered contacts? Jonathan halts, confused to find Wyatt studying his face his eyeglasses in particular.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Huh? Oh - yeah, I tried once, but I was allergic to something in the solution.

dialogues.speaker: WYATT
dialogues.text: Too bad. You have an attractive face. Your eyes especially. Jonathan looks self-conscious in his towel.

dialogues.speaker: WYATT
dialogues.text: It's not a come on, just an observation. (considers him a beat) You don't get much, do you.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: What - you mean sex?

dialogues.speaker: WYATT
dialogues.text: No, flood insurance. How many women have you slept with?

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Oh, I don't know, not a whole-

dialogues.speaker: WYATT
dialogues.text: Of course you know. Everyone knows.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Maybe - four.

dialogues.speaker: WYATT
dialogues.text: Maybe four? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Okay fine, just four. What about you?

dialogues.speaker: WYATT
dialogues.text: Me? I have no idea.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: What? You just said everyone -

dialogues.speaker: WYATT
dialogues.text: I meant everyone like you. Confused, Jonathan looks up -- as Wyatt disappears into a shower stall.

dialogues.speaker: SAME
dialogues.text: Jonathan emerges freshly showered, a towel around his wai as he walks toward the rows of lockers.

dialogues.speaker: WYATT
dialogues.text: Tonight?... Fine. I'm on the list? Jonathan finds Wyatt half-dressed, seated on a bench by a locker and talking on his cell phone.

dialogues.speaker: WYATT
dialogues.text: There better be. Wyatt hangs up, looks up to find Jonathan staring, puzzle

dialogues.speaker: WYATT
dialogues.text: Something wrong? Jonathan reaches into his locker for his hanging jacket, pulls out his own cell phone. It's identical to Wyatt's.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: We have the same phone.

dialogues.speaker: WYATT
dialogues.text: Oh - and you thought I was using yours? I can afford my own phone calls, you know.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: No, I wasn't

dialogues.speaker: WYATT
dialogues.text: I'm pulling your dick, Jonathan. (grins, slams his locker) Actually, I was just firming up some plans for tonight. Are you free? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: (SURPRISED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me? Sure, I guess

dialogues.speaker: WYATT
dialogues.text: You're not. What do you say, are you in?

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: I guess I could go home and change.

dialogues.speaker: WYATT
dialogues.text: To Brooklyn? Forget it, you can borrow something of mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A three-story brownstone in an expensive West Village neighborhood. As Wyatt leads Jonathan to the staircase, t pass a papery-faced GENTLEMAN

dialogues.speaker: WYATT
dialogues.text: t (glances back) This way, Jonathan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Urban chic to a serious degree. Big terrace, funky furnit framed snapshots of Wyatt with similarly hip and attracti young friends - and great art, including an entrancing im of a burning candle just slightly out of focus.

dialogues.speaker: WYATT
dialogues.text: Like it? It's a Gerhard Richter. Kleiner downstairs is a hot shot art dealer - he hooked me up with the gallery in Munich. Wyatt disappears into the next room. Alone, Jonathan wand pauses by the framed snapshots. The young people in them like Wyatt -- beautiful, strong, wealthy. Jonathan pauses one photo in which Wyatt looks a bit younger, his hair bleached blonde and loosely spiked.

dialogues.speaker: WYATT, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Talk about a bad look. Startled, Jonathan quickly turns to find Wyatt standing r behind him,. a slick, expensive SUIT draped over his arm. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WYATT
dialogues.text: Here, try this one. (off Jonathan's hesitation) What?

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Nothing, I just hope I can pull it off.

dialogues.speaker: WYATT
dialogues.text: You hope you can pull it off. You know who you remind me of? James Getz.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: WYATT
dialogues.text: A guy I roomed with freshman year at Princeton.. Real smart                                 - you loosened him up. Only from day one, he just didn't fit in. For starters, he was dirt poor. But it wasn't that. See, there was always this boundary - this wall - between Getz and everyone else. You could argue we laid the foundation, but he built it. Built it by believing the lie.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: What lie?

dialogues.speaker: WYATT
dialogues.text: That he was any different. The clothes, the money, the wry anecdotes - it's all one big masquerade. Anyone can get in, you've just got to wear a costume. But Getz never got that. He assumed he could never scale the wall, when the truth is he was the only one guarding it. It never occurred to him his anonymity could be an asset. No one gets over like the guy who's just a face, an impression. We are - all of us                                                  -

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: So what happened to him?

dialogues.speaker: WYATT
dialogues.text: Who, James Getz? Oh - he killed himself.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: (hesitates a beat) You're pulling my dick, aren't you. Wyatt turns to him with a grave look... then smirks. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WYATT
dialogues.text: With both hands. Jonathan can't help but laugh as Wyatt hands him the suit

dialogues.text: He struts up to us, thumbs in his suspenders:

dialogues.speaker: EMCEE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An ultra-elite "new burlesque" nightclub in Manhattan, Parisian decor. Strictly UPSCALE PATRONS, male and female sip from crystal barware, while on stage a BETTY PAGE TYP performs an elegantly choreographed strip tease. Wyatt and Jonathan sit at a small table; each table is fi with. an old-fashioned black rotary telephone, as well as small monitor recessed into the tabletop on which old sta films play silently. All part of the wink-wink ambience.

dialogues.speaker: WYATT
dialogues.text: It's a little self-conscious, but I thought you'd get a kick out of it. How's that suit working out?

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Oh - great, actually.

dialogues.speaker: WYATT
dialogues.text: Keep it then. I've got two just like it. Jonathan's about to protest, when a WAITRESS arrives.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: Two Macallan 25 year. Enjoy, gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: WYATT

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: The lamest... Wyatt's focused on him, amused, eager to hear it.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Actually, that was probably a few months ago. I was flipping through money magazine and saw this small ad in the back. It read something like "Are. you feeling all alone? Looking to meet women but have forgotten how?" And-there was this number.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Lame enough for you?

dialogues.text: You called a sex ad - from Money Magazine. That is beyond lame. Jonathan too starts laughing - when the phone at their ta lights'up. Wyatt looks to Jonathan, raises a brow - then picks up. He listens a moment, smiles, hands it to Jonath

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: .Hello? Wyatt taps his shoulder, directs his gaze to a SEXY BRUNE at a distant table, receiver to her ear, eyeing Jonathan.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: .All right... Goodbye. Jonathan hangs up, turns to Wyatt.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN

dialogues.speaker: ON THE DANCE FLOOR
dialogues.text: Jonathan is slow dancing with the sexy Brunette to an old Edith Piaf ballad. He looks over her shoulder to his tabl where Wyatt is sitting, talking on his cell phone. Glancing up, Wyatt's eyes meet Jonathan's; he flashes a p smile. Jonathan continues dancing, truly enjoying himself The Brunette leans in, whispers something in his ear...

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO WYATT AND JONATHAN'S TABLE
dialogues.text: Wyatt clicks off his cell phone, looks up to find Jonatha returning alone, looking deflated.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: She's a hooker. Wyatt shrugs, grinning.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN

dialogues.text: That depends on what you mean by that word. Stretch the definition and you could incorporate most of the men as well. (sips his drink) You know in Amsterdam prostitutes not only belong to a union, they have to pay taxes.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: You seem to possess quite a store of international trivia.

dialogues.speaker: WYATT
dialogues.text: Not really. I just get around... Jonathan, relax. It's not like she just shot your dog. I was only trying to help. Besides, what are you looking for - a relationship? As if you have time for one? This was your first day off in how long?

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Three weeks.

dialogues.speaker: WYATT
dialogues.text: Four for me. Face it, we've mortgaged our youth. Pimped out our twenties. But we still have needs. And there's nothing shameful about wanting them met. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: So you sleep with hookers?

dialogues.speaker: WYATT
dialogues.text: (LAUGHING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me? Never.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: So how do you - meet your needs? Wyatt studies him a beat, another French love song drifti in the background as the Emcee introduces a new girl.

dialogues.speaker: WYATT
dialogues.text: What if I told you... (breaks off, laughs) Christ, I sound like an infommercial.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN

dialogues.speaker: WYATT
dialogues.text: Listen. You don't think that women have these same urges? Young women, just like ourselves, successful and working their asses off to stay that way? You better believe they do.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: And?

dialogues.speaker: WYATT
dialogues.text: And - well - let's just say, there's a way...a way it can be taken care of.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: You make it sound like a mob hit. Wyatt smiles, and turns his attention back to the floor s

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: What you were talking about, before. Peoples' needs... Wyatt turns to Jonathan with a grin:

dialogues.speaker: WYATT

Pedestrians and theatre crowds pass by as he remains root to the spot,.hoping he'll see that face in the crowd. After a while he shakes his head at the ridiculousness of and heads down into the-subway.

Like Rutherford Ster conference room, this one too is designed with a glass wa Jonathan peers out at workers passing in utter indifferen to him. Slightly different tank, slightly different fish. dialogues.text: Along the entire square of ledge, throngs of SUITED BUSIN TYPES bundled in scarves eating street vendor fare. It's we find Wyatt and Jonathan, having a quick bite.

dialogues.text: I wonder what the Founding Fathers would make of this scene. Wyatt regards face after face of young men and women wear expensive suits, wolfing down lunch so they can get back work - a good 2/3 of them talking on cell phones as they

They both instinctively reach in thei jackets, take out their identical phones. It's Wyatt's th ringing. Jonathan rests his down on the ledge.

dialogues.text: They are headed for a room as he ventures another questio

dialogues.text: On a level with this feller? He points to 'Duck on bike' watching over them like a cha

Jonathan gapes, horrified, the world crashing in on him j as he senses something behind him and BANG! him to the back of the head -- he goes down like a sack o potatoes. BLACKOUT.

dialogues.text: .I saw blood on the bed and then someone hit me. When I came to, she was gone.

dialogues.text: I don't

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes

In the far corner rests his racket bag. He grabs it, yank open the zipper... his face draining of all remaining col as he peers into his empty racket ba

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN

And where is she?! If you hurt her I swear to God I'll... Jonathan falters, unsure where he's going with this and realizing he's now talking to himself.

dialogues.speaker: TO-SEND-THIS-MESSAGE--PRESS-POUND-OR-
dialogues.text: simply-hang-up. To-erase-and-record-a-new- messa ge---press-Star. Jonathan hesitates, hits the Star key. A new BEEP. Harder

Jonathan spins, scans t room, grabs the nearest blunt object: his tennis trophy. QUICKLY CUT SHOTS of Jonathan searching his apartment, hi trophy raised as a makeshift weapon. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: He finally halts, uneasy but satisfied there's no one els here - when his home phone rings, startling him. RING... RING... RING... Jonathan hesitates. His machine picks up:

dialogues.speaker: PETERSON
dialogues.text: I understand you were out today. I left messages on your cell but never heard back, so I thought I'd try you at home. He slowly lowers his trophy as he listens, staring out th window at the dark night and empty street below.

dialogues.speaker: PETERSON
dialogues.text: Just want to make sure you're up to speed with Weiss Murphy, because the folks at Clute Nichols are expecting you...

dialogues.text: They're our biggest client, so needless to say, make them your top priority... Jonathan takes out the crinkled Chinese gum wrapper. He stares at it with a look of longing: this is his Priority

They all shake their hea Heading back for the subway, dejected, he steps on.a discarded page from the newspaper's Metro section, sees a headline: "STILL NO SUSPECT IN MURDER OF YOUNG EXEC." The photo is of Simone Forester.

dialogues.text: Intensely preoccupied, Jonathan walks alone past assistan and execs. In his eyes a sense of paranoia, a mistrust of every strange face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonathan exits, starts toward the sidewalk -- but hears something: sandpaper SHUFFLE of shoes on pavement. Be spi No one there. Just one of many large stone pillars adorni the building. Jonathan peers anxiously at the pillar, wavering. He steps closer, trying to glimpse behind it - RING! of his cell-phone breaks the stillness. RING... RIN He catches his breath, quickly picks up. A silent beat.

dialogues.speaker: A WOMAN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Are you free tonight?... Hello? He hangs up, chilled. Turns again to the pillar, steps cl - no sound. He hesitates... then turns and walks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A narrow, curved stretch of grimy walls of ads and graffi Jonathan keeps a quick pace, feeling vulnerable. We lag back, following him from an ANONYMOUS POV; glance at a sign for stairs to the N & R trains.

dialogues.text: Jonathan is waiting for his train, eyes nervously glancin around, still feeling watched - When he sees a young woman standing all the way across on opposite platform, waiting for a train. She casually turn her head, and Jonathan's eyes go wide... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: It's "S." Jonathan just gapes across the divide of two subway track he can't believe he's seeing her again... . when she starts to back away, almost as if she might ru Confused, Jonathan rushes to the edge of his platform.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: wait! Wait, right there! Jonathan stands on the edge reeling, desperate to get,to He looks around, hears the distant: .nimble of afar. off and suddenly he does something we'd have never thought hi capable of: he jumps onto the tracks! He lands hard, nearly breaking his ankle, but quickly scrambles to his feet, splashing in the sludge between ra eyes darting along the track, anxious to avoid the third rail, ears attuned to the sound of that distant train as races for

dialogues.text: He reaches the grimy rungs and quickly climbs up. He gets to his feet on the center divider - now only one of track separating him from the platform she was standin - only she's no longer there? He scans the people waiting, no sign of "S" among them - then suddenly he spots her, heading for the exits.

dialogues.speaker: STOP
dialogues.text: She glances back, utterly stunned to find Jonathan standi on the center divider, feet soaked in muck. Neither speaks for a moment, just staring at each other across the solitary track. Then:

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: I thought you were dead! She looks like she wants to say something, but doesn't. A all at once he's hit with a crushing realization:

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: How do you know him? (off her silence) Damn it answer me! She halts, slowly looks back at him. of camГўВЂВћ Through the club. He caught me trying to steal his wallet. Jonathan looks confused; she's struggling to stay compose but looks like she could break down at any moment. ГўВЂВћSГўВЂВћ He asked if I wanted to make some real money. All I had to do was get involved with you, and not ask any questions. Jonathan just stares, devastated.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: So everything between us - was nothing? She fights back tears.

dialogues.speaker: ., S
dialogues.text: No - no... After that first night I tried to call it off, he said he'd kill me if I didn't go through with it.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Go through with what? ГўВЂВћC,. The plan. Get you out of the hotel room, slip out and meet up later for my money. Only I ran instead. He's been looking for me ever since. I have to leave the city -

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Then why didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: S
dialogues.text: Because I needed to see you again. I needed to be sure you were all right. Despite his conflicting emotions, Jonathan is moved S,f I didn't know how to find you - you were just a number in a cell phone, and (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: 'is" Jonathan had taken that. I remembered you took this train -

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: He killed a woman from the club, someone I'd been with. "S" is shocked., instantly terrified. Clearly she had no I/ S$f Jonathan, you have to leave! Do you understand? You need to get the hell out of here, he's going to kill you! The roar of the incoming train is growing LOUDER... Don't you understand? He's going to kill - - when the INCOMING TRAIN completely drowns him out... an swipes "S" out of Jonathan's view. Jonathan struggles to peer through the train windows but passengers prevent him from getting a look at her. Just t the TRAIN DOORS OPEN WITH THE NOISE of passengers getting and off. Panicked, Jonathan cranes his neck, trying to se her through the windows.

dialogues.speaker: STOP

dialogues.speaker: CONDUCTOR, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Shuttle to New York's Grand Central Station. Grand Central is next. He jumps off the train, in the direction she'd been walki -- only she's nowhere in sight. Jonathan spins franticall the doors close and he hears the TRAIN START TO PULL AWAY He runs alongside the train - desperately searching for a glimpse of her .until the last car passes the rear observation window, her hand pressed to the pane her tearful expression bidding him a heartbreaking goodby He stumbles to a devastated halt, eyes pleading vainly as watches her recede, framed by the rectangle of window, directly beneath it the train's steel. exterior labelled shuttle line's circled black and white S.

A man's hand extends a handkerchief from the seat behind ГўВЂВћSГўВЂВћ No thank you. RACK FOCUS on the man withdrawing his handkerchief behind her, grinning coolly to himself: it's-Wyatt.

dialogues.text: Jonathan MesserГўВЂВ” Jonathan hangs up. Takes an angry breath. Presses redial.

RING... RING... RING... RING... RING -- a CLICK someone picking up, then SILENCE and faint wisps of stati

dialogues.speaker: WYATT'S VOICE

dialogues.speaker: WYATT'S VOICE
dialogues.text: - they're here to stay, Oh I believe

dialogues.speaker: WYATT'S VOICE
dialogues.text: - in yester--

dialogues.text: I'm going to find you, you hear me? I'm- CLICK. Dead air.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: Hello?... Hello?! Jonathan SLAMS the phone down, tension in his face joined a new emotion, something closer to. fury.

dialogues.speaker: JONATHAN
dialogues.text: I'm going to find you.

dialogues.text: Jonathan is heading for the Clute Nichols building, that focused tension on his face -

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Mr. Messer? Jonathan is too lost in thought to hear it.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Jonathan. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RUSSO
dialogues.text: On that missing girl of yours. The.one whose name began with. an "S." Have any luck finding her? Jonathan absently tightens his grasp on his briefcase.

dialogues.text: No. No luck.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSO

dialogues.speaker: RUSSO

Widen to find the post-its organized with his u fastidiousness "Wyatt Bose = William Bansky" and other random scribbling He's trying to apply his mathematical mind to his crisis, hoping to conjure some kind of pattern or logic to it all Reverse angle through the glass: to anyone passing, he lo like your typical overly meticulous, isolated auditor. Closer on Jonathan as he clutches the table, looks second away from utterly losing it -- when something suddenly oc to him. He whips around, gaze fixing on (CONTINUED)

dialogues.text: Jonathan and Black Business Suit come in. She starts to
